5. Lack of iteration ♻️

ChatGPT can only generate text based on the patterns it has seen during its training, it can't learn from feedback or improve based on new information.

This is something humans learn to do when they are toddlers.

2. Lack of understanding 🧠

ChatGPT generates text that appears coherent, but it doesn't understand the meaning or context of the words it uses. 

This is why it often requires a human to edit the text.

1. Lack of creativity 🎨

ChatGPT can generate text based on patterns and examples it has seen, but it lacks the ability to come up with truly original ideas. 

It will never write the next 'Hamlet' or 'Hamilton'

More tricks & tutorials coming soon (follow me to stay in the loop).

7/ Only supports text

ChatGPT is a textual model. It doesn't support images or videos.

It does generate good prompts for Midjourney. In that sense, it can indirectly create images.

However, it can't ingest images as prompt, which would be useful to generate code from designs.

5/ Wrong answers

ChatGPT provides incomplete or wrong answers at times. Even with the best prompts, it sometimes messes up (confidently!).

Wear your critical thinking and review ChatGPT's output with (at least) the same amount of diligence you'd use to review a colleague's PR.

2/ Outdated data

ChatGPT's was trained on data that is 1.5 years old. The most recent data is from September 2021.

While this is ok for greenfield or older stacks. It has limitations for anything that depends on recent events, such as framework updates and security patches.

1/ Legal risks

If you upload code to ChatGPT (or other such AI tools), you should treat it as if you're making it publicly available, as it might should as a recommendation to other users.

If it's your company's code, then you might be breaking the IP clauses in your contract.

4/ Now you're ready to fine-tune ChatGPT with your dataset. This process involves training the model on your dataset to adjust its parameters and improve its performance on your specific task or industry. #ChatGPT #Training

🔔 Request a specific format

Indicating a specific format, such as a list, table, or graph, will ensure ChatGPT returns texts in those formats. https://t.co/iiolytt3iV

🔔 Indicate a language or style

Specifying the language or style helps ChatGPT understand the tone and approach to take when generating the response (e.g. formal, casual, professional, conversational). https://t.co/klFrzdD2be

🔔 Use specific keywords

Including specific keywords related to the task or question can help ChatGPT comprehend the intent of the prompt and generate a more accurate response. https://t.co/KpWSn57m3P

🔔 Provide context

Provide necessary information to give ChatGPT a clear understanding of the task or question at hand. This will return answers more tailored to your needs. https://t.co/PYhXmcDZPp

🔔 Write unique prompts

This is an effective way to encourage ChatGPT to generate creative and original responses. 

Provide original concepts or ideas using specific keywords, tasks, or questions requiring the model to think creatively. https://t.co/e6A8qti97w

5. Editing and proof-reading. 
ChatGPT is an excellent editor, not just for grammar and spelling, but also syntax, particularly for #academicwriting. Try pasting in a sentence or paragraph and ask for specific improvement for an academic context.

4. Sharing your research to non-academic audiences - like #socialmedia!
Ask ChatGPT to help promote your #research, achievements and outputs by creating #Twitter or #LinkedIn length posts about your research milestones. You can even ask it to funny, poetic or any other style!

2. Sourcing background or contextual statistics.
Prompt ChatGPT to find key statistics that may be useful when describing the background or context of your research. Prompt it to name its source, and always double check the accuracy of the information directly.

1. Brainstorming new avenues of #research, or finding knowledge gaps.
ChatGPT can do a pretty remarkable job of summarising some of the key challenges in a specific research field. This can be great for brainstorming new project ideas or prompting topics for a #literaturereview!*

Emotion: I don't have emotions, so I can't provide emotional support or understanding.
#ChatGPT

Common Sense: Common sense knowledge and understanding is something that humans acquire through life experience, but I don't have life experience and may not understand the implications of certain statements or actions in the way that a human would.
#ChatGPT

Creativity: While I can generate new text based on patterns in my training data, I do not have my own thoughts or imagination, thus I can't come up with new ideas or concept from scratch.
#ChatGPT

Understanding Context: I am a machine and may not fully understand the nuances and subtleties of human language and communication, which can lead to confusion or misinterpretation of what is being said.
#ChatGPT

As an AI, I have several limitations:
Knowledge: My knowledge is based on the data that was used to train me and my knowledge cut-off date, so I may not have information on recent events or developments.
#ChatGPT

5/ Generate test cases

Ain't nothing better than code with solid code coverage. Yep - ChatGPT can write those too. You can ask it things like "what test cases should I include in a weather app?" or even a specific function you want test cases written for.

3/ Animations and transitions

A tedious task for developers, expecially when working with ambitious designers, but ChatGPT can get you more than 50% of the way there. It can quickly generate animations and transitions, or provide a good start for more complex visuals.

2/ Generate documentation

Definitely not one of our favourite tasks, but now there's no excuse. Paste your functions or code snippets and ChatGPT will provide clean documentation. After all, it's superpower IS natural language processing.

Some rules for making ChatGPT produce better writing:
1) Remember you are prompting an AI, not talking to a person
2) More specific & elaborate prompts work better
3) Ask it to take on a role or persona
4) Tell it to edit & change what doesn’t work

@johndyer Right now, in the most primitive state, ChatGPT can answer Bible questions more accurate than any preacher or pastor of today. Remember kids, ChatGPT don’t mix feelings or personal emotions. It will answer the truth only. It will not guess, be interpretive or even create a rule.

Incorrect uses of ChatGPT:

• Using the model to generate false or misleading information.

• Using the model to impersonate a real person or organization.

• Using the model to create spam or unwanted content.

Correct uses of ChatGPT:

• Generating human-like text for tasks such as chatbot conversations, story writing, and language translation.

• Answering questions and providing information on a wide range of topics.

• Summarizing text or providing a summary of key points.

ChatGPT could be used to generate informational messages or resources for the community.

If a community member asks for help with a technical issue, ChatGPT could be used to generate a response with troubleshooting steps.

Moderating discussions:

Text:
You might wonder if the AI evolution is good for the humankind. Idk, but see ChatGPT. 

It's future can be bright or dark, depending on how and for what purpose we use it.

👉Learning: ChatGPT can assist programmers in learning new programming languages, libraries or frameworks by providing examples, explanations and tutorials
👉Research: ChatGPT can assist programmers in researching specific topics or finding relevant information related to a programming project, such as new libraries or frameworks.
👉Debugging and troubleshooting: ChatGPT can be used to understand code snippets and help programmers identify bugs or issues with their code.

👉Code generation: ChatGPT can be trained to generate code in a specific programming language based on natural language inputs. This can save programmers time and effort when writing repetitive or complex code.

*taps mic*

ChatGPT is a research project, not a product that will be available forever and especially won’t always be free. 

So maybe you shouldn’t be basing your entire persona or strategy around it.

Inb4: ChatGPT has obvious limitations. It's answers are incomplete or wrong sometimes.

In my 13 years of experience writing and reviewing code, critical thinking is a must-have skill, both with humans and with AI.

Don't push ChatGPT's responses to prod without reviewing first.

2/ Research and compare

Many times there are different ways to implement something. So my usual approach is to build a rough PoC of two competing approaches and compare.

ChatGPT can do it for me:
- React vs Vue
- Algorithm A or B
- etc

This saves half day of work, easily. https://t.co/C1Yp1YKkK0
